user.biography: Integrated architecture, landscape architecture, interior architecture, product design and graphic design.

node.text:
Because of its significant environmental impacts, advancing the carbon footprint of the construction industry is an important part of finding future-proof solutions.

In the project Biocrete, Snøhetta teamed up with some of Norway’s most experienced contractors, researchers, producers and suppliers within the concrete and biochar industry, aiming to develop a net carbon negative concrete. By pyrolyzing scraps, cut offs and waste wood from the construction industry, biochar is made. When mixed in with the cement, the CO2 is sequestered at such a scale that the CO2 emissions from the concrete production are compensated for by the carbon in the biochar. The collaboration resulted in the first net carbon-negative precast concrete wall being cast on March 16 in Orkanger, Norway.

By both combating a growing waste problem and the world’s increasing CO2 emissions, this solution has the potential to significantly decrease the environmental footprint of this widely used material and contribute to making concrete a much-needed planet-positive contribution for specific applications.

node.text:
As the most widely used building material in the world, concrete plays a significant role in the carbon footprint of the building and construction industry. Its key component, cement, is the source of about 8 % of the world's CO2 emissions, according to think tank Chatham House. 

The chemical and thermal combustion processes involved in the production of cement places the material with CO2 emissions above aviation fuel (2.5 %) and not far behind agriculture (12 %). To reach the goals of the Paris Agreement, annual global CO2 emissions linked to concrete will need to fall by steeply in the next few years. 

As a response to this, Snøhetta has entered a strategic partnership with Norwegian startup Saferock to pilot and market the production of a more sustainable concrete. 

By utilizing industrial by-products to make geopolymer concrete, Snøhetta and Saferock estimates that carbon emissions associated with the production of concrete can be reduced by more than 70 % as a first step. By 2025, the aim is to produce fully CO2 neutral concrete.

More info at snohetta.com and saferock.no

Video by @bjornar_ovrebo and @kjetilandersen

node.title: Geopolymer concrete – the construction material of the future?

node.text:
Here’s a little video showcasing more of our design for the new ASI Reisen headquarters in Natters, Austria. By offering solutions that will enable the long-term low environmental footprint of the office space, this flexible and open office space over several floors constitutes a healthy and enjoyable working environment for its users. The building is tailor-made for the needs of ASI Reisen and reflects the values of the company in an intuitive and generous way.

Video by Stefan Krösbacher

node.text: Have a look at the new mini documentary about Snøhetta, created in collaboration with @visitnorway. In the film, we are discussing how architecture interacts with nature, our philosophy, and what role the Norwegian nature has played for some of our most renowned projects. The full video can be watched on our IGTV-channel, or via the link in our bio. #visitnorway #osloopera #peergynt 📷 @willynikkers

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on August 17, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
The additional exhibition spaces at @ordrupgaard dedicated to the museum’s impressionistic art are made up of two smaller and one larger space in a light color and material palette. The spaces are designed in close collaboration with the museum and are all furnished with oak floors, walls, and ceilings, providing a light, organic and warm atmosphere. Gypsum boards are mounted on the walls allowing for the museum to effortlessly curate art pieces and change the color palette of each exhibition room when needed. The exhibition ceilings are covered with oak veneer cassettes with carefully integrated light installations, providing a seamless and harmonious design that places the art pieces at the center of attention.

Contrasting with the reflective steel exterior that is partially visible from the outside, the inside of the exhibition spaces creates a sense of softness and comfort, echoing almost the design of a classic vintage jewelry box, with its hard, metallic exterior and soft, velvety lining on the inside.

📷 @laura_stamer

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on August 17, 2021. May be an image of indoor.
Photo by Snøhetta on August 17, 2021.

node.text:
Originally built as a three-winged country mansion in the neo-classical style during World War I, @ordrupgaard was expanded by a modern 1,150 m2 glass and black lava concrete extension in 2005, designed by @zahahadidarchitects. Snøhetta’s design, most of which is underground, but also partly excavated from the landscape, creates a holistic and continuous path throughout the entire museum and its surrounding park and gardens, linking Hadid’s extension for special exhibitions with the museum’s original building and permanent collection. 

The largest of the three main exhibition spaces designed by Snøhetta can be partly seen from the outside as a monolithic, steel-coated sculpturesque structure that seems somewhat excavated from a larger volume below ground. Just like a hidden treasure that reveals itself as it appears during excavation, the structure glistens in the landscape. Cut in a wide range of different facets and polished in different directions, the structure creates a play of light throughout the days and shifting seasons. 

📷 @laura_stamer

node.text:
Today marks the opening of our new extension and landscape for @ordrupgaard in Denmark. Situated in Charlottenlund, north of Copenhagen, Ordrupgaard houses Northern Europe’s most comprehensive collection of French and Danish art from the 19th and early 20th century. 

Conceptually dubbed “Himmelhaven” (“Heaven’s Garden”) the extension exterior is very much a “clin d’œil” to the impressionistic art period, characterized by its constant efforts to capture light and its changing qualities, and immortalized on canvases by world-renowned artists such as Manet, Monet, Degas, and Renoir.

Referred to by the architects as a “third parterre”, Snøhetta’s extension marks a continuation of the landscape and is placed at the intersection of Ordrupgaard’s English style park with its deciduous trees, many of them fruit bearing, and an adjacent smaller French-inspired rose garden.

See snohetta.com for more! 

📷 @laura_stamer

node.text:
In 1937, a harbor bath was built on Knubben, a 750 square meter skerry just outside of Arendal city center. The public facility boasted a ten-meter diving platform, a children’s pool, changing rooms and a kiosk, and is known as one of the clearest examples of functionalistic architecture in Norway from the same time period. In 1947, the harbor bath closed its doors before being taken back into use during the 1960s, this time as a jazz club. After substantial decay however, the diving platform was demolished by the Norwegian Armed Forces in the 1980s.

In 2018, Snøhetta was commissioned to revitalize the facility with a feasibility study. The new Knubben will rise as a man-made structure founded on steel core piles with architecture that draws inspiration from the shapes we find in the islets and skerries along the Norwegian coast. It will resemble a block of stone shaped during the Last Glacial Period, characterized by abraded shapes where soft concave and convex walls form cavities in the landscape. To represent the terrain as accurately as possible, the construction will consist of horizontal layers following the contour lines of a map.

As a robust skerry that can withstand rough conditions, Knubben will be a lively meeting place that can be used all year round. The facility will accommodate an open-air stage alongside an amphitheater, creating a setting for all kinds of performances. In addition, Knubben will house indoor areas for both a restaurant and more intimate concerts.

As we become increasingly urban, we long for contact with nature. Knubben will be a social meeting place that provides a sensation of closeness to the sea, and will serve as a backdrop to a plethora of activities and experiences. It will be a soothing spot in the sun on a hot summer evening, a hub for cultural events, and a place to enjoy a good meal after taking an icy bath on a cold winter’s day.

📷 Aesthetica Studio

node.text:
The Swarovski Playtower, situated in the magnificent park of the Swarovski @kristallwelten, offers a wide range of playing experiences in a five-story transparent structure. This summer, the artists, clowns, and acrobats of @circustheaterroncalli returned to the Kristallwelten and used the exterior of the Playtower as their playscape to present their circus arts. The Playtower gives an excellent backdrop for the exciting performances of the artists. If you have the chance to visit Swarovksi Kristallwelten, there is showtime until August 29.

📷 Peter Zöch

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on August 06, 2021. May be an image of 2 people.

node.text:
Those born in the beginning of the last century are the last living generation to have experienced changes that have had a tremendous physical impact on humanity in the western world. They witnessed two world wars, worldwide changes in transportation, power supply transitions, revolutions, industrialization, and the overwhelming introduction of the digital era. Some of them lived through this transition in the northernmost parts of the world, where the introduction of electricity undoubtedly impacted the dark winters. 

In 2014, we joined forces with Zumtobel Group (@zumtobelgroup), photographer Sølve Sundsbø (@solvesundsbostudio), and authors Åsne Seierstad (@asneseierstad) and Po Tidholm (@po.tidholm) to learn from some of these people. 

Interviewing four people over the age of 100 who had lived their entire lives above the Arctic Circle, we explored the effects on living in, and in the absence of, Nordic Light. 

📷 Calle Huth (@callehuth) & Snøhetta

node.text:
We are excited to see this project from 2007 continuing to enthuse visitors! At @kivikart in Skåne, Sweden, Snøhetta and Norwegian artist and photographer Tom Sandberg (@t.sandbergart) created a series of explorations of the spatial and temporal relationship between photography, architecture and landscape.

Captured here is @sofiabertilsson inside the sculpture Viewfinder, photographed by Albert Wiking, first published at @artinsiderpr.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta in Natters, Tirol, Austria. May be an image of tree and outdoors.

node.text:
At Snøhetta's timber office building for international trekking and adventure travel company ASI Reisen a “green curtain” of climbing plants grows on a suspended metal frame, ensuring the building blends harmoniously into its verdant forest surroundings. It also serves as a glare shield and for shading the generous glass surfaces. The 118 climbing plants change the appearance of the façade throughout the year and thus also adapt to seasonal thermal insulation needs. 

The microclimate created by this green buffer zone reduces the energy required for cooling the building. Natural ventilation using thermal lift and wind pressure conditions circulates fresh air inside the building. The constantly monitored room climate regulates how wide and how long the ventilation flaps are open. 

📷 Christian Flatscher

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta in San Francisco, California. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Nearly tripling the amount of exhibition space, we also made sure to include spaces to relax and reflect in the expansion of the @sfmoma. One of the large windows opening out towards the city serves this exact purpose, while also bringing plenty of daylight into the building. Turns out it’s also popular with the kids, as documented here by @vasu_virajsilp. 

"I remember that day while we were walking and experiencing the space in MoMa SF. My son, Davyn, happened to walk ahead of us to this window alcove. He went straight there, climbed up and stood on it. Then I saw the beautiful daylight casting upon him so I started to take photographs of him while he was walking like he was on the runway. He really enjoyed this window nook!"

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on July 29, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text: Welcome to nature! The logo for Norway’s National Parks represents a portal into to nature. As an entrance or gate, it symbolizes the transition between two dimensions – the traversing between the cultivated and the natural. At the same time, it is a protective frame, reminding us to be both visitors and preservers of the beauty that lies ahead.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on July 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text: We're excited to unveil the new expansion and site redesign at the Joslyn Art Museum, developed in partnership with local architects Alley Poyner Macchietto Architecture! The new 42,000-square-foot pavilion will add light-filled galleries designed to meet the demands and explore the possibilities of a growing permanent collection, including works from the nationally renowned Phillip G. Schrager Collection of Contemporary Art. Find out more about the expansion on our website.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Snøhetta on July 26, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and outdoors.

node.text:
Snøhetta's projects respond with clear structures that grow out of the complexities and the contextual examinations of a site. At New York City’s Times Square, we not just doubled the amount of usable public space for pedestrians, but transformed a congested vehicular district into a world-class civic space. The design is inspired by Times Square’s past and its rich entertainment history – a duality that influenced both the larger concept and the project’s details. The new “Crossroads of the World” embraces its role as a stage for public life and the freedom of expression.

📷 Michael Grimm
